item.title: Attack Sets Off Hunt for Tunisian Who Had Slipped Germany’s Grasp
item.media:description: A truck trailer stood among destroyed Christmas market stalls in Berlin on Tuesday, the day after the attack that left 12 dead and 48 injured. At center is the Kaiser Wilhelm Memorial Church.
item.description: The identity of the Tunisian, Anis Amri, who had been labeled a security threat and was supposed to have been deported months ago, alarmed intelligence officials.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY, JACK EWING, JOANNA BERENDT and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Berlin Attack Poses Toughest Test in Merkel’s 11 Years in Power
item.media:description: The German chancellor, Angela Merkel, and Mayor Michael Müller of Berlin on Tuesday at the site of an attack that left 12 people dead.
item.description: The assault has rendered the chancellor, whose party has already suffered defeats in bellwether votes, more vulnerable as national elections approach in 2017.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Erdogan Says Follower of Gulen, His Rival, Killed Russian Envoy
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey in Istanbul this week. The Russian government has been far more cautious in public statements about the killer’s possible affiliation or motive.
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan doubled down on accusations that the assassin’s fealty lay with Fethullah Gulen, an outlawed Muslim cleric.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Italy Overwhelmed
item.description: Italy is overwhelmed by the influx of migrants. But three citizens are making a difference in migrants’ lives, and even in their deaths.
item.dc:creator: DAN RUETENIK
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: U.N. Inquiry Alludes to Russia and Syria as Bombers of Aid Convoy
item.media:description: The scene on Sept. 20, the morning after a deadly attack on a convoy delivering aid on the outskirts of Aleppo, Syria.
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: A panel created to investigate the deadly Sept. 19 assault on a humanitarian aid convoy in northern Syria said bombs from aircraft were responsible.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: U.N. Council to Vote Thursday on End to Israeli Settlements
item.description: The United Nations Security Council is due to vote on Thursday on a draft resolution that would demand that Israel "immediately and completely cease all settlement activities in the occupied Palestinian territory, including East Jerusalem."
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Dispatches: On Patrol With Police as Philippines Battles Drugs
item.media:description: In Manila last month, the Santa Ana station jail — a single cell, about 12 feet wide by 20 feet deep — held 48 men and had a single toilet.
item.description: A reporter heads out with officers to see, from their perspective, the nation’s deadly crackdown on drug users and dealers.
item.dc:creator: AURORA ALMENDRAL

item.title: Hyundai’s U.S. Chief Is Out, as Automaker Seeks to Rekindle Growth
item.description: David Zuchowski had led the American unit of the South Korean company for two years, as the U.S. market shifted away from Hyundai’s strengths.
item.dc:creator: NEAL E. BOUDETTE

item.title: Taliban Attack Lawmaker’s Kabul Home
item.media:description: Security forces on Wednesday patrolling the site of an attack on the home of Mir Wali, a lawmaker, in Kabul, Afghanistan.
item.description: The lawmaker, Mir Wali, is a prominent figure in the southern province of Helmand, and his family has long been a target of the militant group.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Despite Fatal Blast, Mexicans Clamor to Rebuild Fireworks Market
item.media:description: An investigator on Wednesday stood amid the wreckage of houses destroyed in an explosion at the San Pablito fireworks market.
item.description: As families congregated in hospitals to visit loved ones or look for the missing, there was scarcely a word of criticism for the failings in accountability that led to the fire.
item.dc:creator: PAULINA VILLEGAS and AZAM AHMED

item.title: Nearly 300 Are Arrested in Congo as Protests Appear to Wane
item.media:description: Roman Catholic bishops arriving to mediate talks between the opposition and the government of President Joseph Kabila in Kinshasa, the capital of the Democratic Republic of Congo, on Wednesday. The church has assumed the responsibility of trying to prevent the crisis from spinning out of control.
item.description: Sporadic gunfire rang out over Kinshasa, and witnesses reported clashes in Lubumbashi, but nothing on the scale of the violence on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: What in the World: On the Trail of Italy’s Manger Hoppers
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.description: Visiting one church after another to see their elaborate Nativity scenes is a popular holiday activity in Italy. Here are some favorites in Rome.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Spiking Temperatures in the Arctic Startle Scientists
item.media:description: The cruise ship Crystal Serenity, anchored outside Nome, Alaska, in August, before its inaugural voyage through the Northwest Passage. The trip would not have been possible before climate change led to diminished sea ice coverage.
item.description: A spate of extreme warmth is linked to climate change, and may lead to shrinking ice coverage and even more warming in the region, scientists said.
item.dc:creator: HENRY FOUNTAIN and JOHN SCHWARTZ

item.title: Hezbollah Is Using U.S.-Made Military Vehicles in Syria, Israel Says
item.description: If American-made armored personnel carriers passed to Hezbollah from the Lebanese Army, as an Israeli official said, that might point to a broader leakage of weapons.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and BEN HUBBARD
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Romania Set for First Female, and First Muslim, Prime Minister
item.media:description: Sevil Shhaideh is a relatively little-known figure who served as minister of regional development for six months in Romania’s last Social Democrat-led government.
item.description: Sevil Shhaideh, a relatively little-known figure in Romanian politics, was nominated by the majority Social Democratic Party.
item.dc:creator: KIT GILLET

item.title: Spanish Banks Ordered to Repay Customers Over Unfair Mortgages
item.media:description: BBVA, one of Spain’s largest banks, said it expected a European Court of Justice ruling on Wednesday to reduce its profit by about 404 million euros.
item.description: The ruling centered on the use of a clause in mortgage contracts that meant banks did not have to pass on the full savings from falling interest rates.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: YouTube Stars Say They Were Removed From Delta Flight for Speaking Arabic
item.media:description: Adam Saleh, center, and Slim Albaher, right, after arriving at Kennedy International Airport on Wednesday. The men said they had been asked to leave their flight at Heathrow Airport after Mr. Saleh spoke in Arabic to his mother by phone.
item.media:credit: Kevin Hagen for The New York Times
item.description: Delta stood by its actions, saying the two customers, Adam Saleh and Slim Albaher, had “sought to disrupt the cabin with provocative behavior, including shouting.”
item.dc:creator: JONAH ENGEL BROMWICH

item.title: Erdogan Embraces Bana al-Abed, Who Brought Child’s View of Aleppo to Twitter
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey hugged Bana al-Abed, a 7-year-old girl from Aleppo.
item.description: Bana became a global sensation over the past few months for messages and videos posted to her Twitter account describing the horrors of Syria’s war in intimate detail.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER

item.title: Sinosphere: Smog Grips China, but Exam Goes on Outdoors
item.description: Pupils wore flimsy masks that afforded little protection and quickly came to symbolize the frustration that people feel about the pollution.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Donald Trump, Seeking Ambassadors, Sorts Through Competing Priorities
item.media:description: President-elect Donald J. Trump was greeted by Gov. Terry E. Branstad of Iowa, his nominee for ambassador to China, at a “thank you” rally in Des Moines this month.
item.description: Intense jockeying for diplomatic posts has begun among donors and loyalists to Mr. Trump and, in some cases, among people close to his children.
item.dc:creator: MAGGIE HABERMAN

item.title: Germany Seeks Tunisian Tied to Berlin Christmas Market Attack
item.media:description: Anis Amri is wanted by German police in connection with the Berlin Christmas market attack.
item.description: The man was denied asylum in Germany and was considered a security risk. He is wanted in connection with a truck attack that killed 12 people and hurt 48.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Nigel Farage Called a ‘Disgrace’ for Remarks About Berlin Attack
item.media:description: Nigel Farage, former leader of the U.K. Independence Party, in London in November.
item.description: The former UKIP leader blamed the terrorist assault on Angela Merkel’s refugee policy, then impugned the husband of a British lawmaker murdered by a right-wing extremist.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: James Taylor Cancels Concert in Philippines, Citing Bloody Antidrug Campaign
item.media:description: A billboard on Wednesday promoting the James Taylor concert in Manila. Mr. Taylor said the decision would not affect plans for the rest of his tour.
item.description: The musician said reports of “summary executions of suspected offenders without trial or judicial process” in the Philippines were “deeply concerning.”
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: Sinosphere: ‘Great Wall’ Producer on What Hollywood and China Can Teach Each Other
item.media:description: Matt Damon plays a mercenary in “The Great Wall,” Zhang Yimou’s epic thriller in which monsters face off against humanity at the Great Wall of China.
item.description: Peter Loehr, chief of Legendary East, discusses the making of the $150 million co-production, the biggest so far, and criticism over the casting of its star, Matt Damon.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: At Least 20 Reported Dead as Congolese Security Forces Fire on Protesters
item.media:description: Scattered protests started on Tuesday in Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of Congo.
item.description: The protesters, in Kinshasa and other cities, were demanding that President Joseph Kabila step down after his second term expired with no election scheduled.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Russia, Iran and Turkey Meet for Syria Talks, Excluding U.S.
item.description: The new alignment and the absence of any Western powers at the table all but guarantee that President Bashar al-Assad will continue to rule Syria under any resulting agreement.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: 2 Brazilian Companies Are Said to Be Settling Bribery Case
item.media:description: A Braskem S.A. petrochemical plant in Brazil in 2015. Braskem and Odebrecht could pay a total of $3 billion in a settlement.
item.description: Odebrecht and Braskem S.A., which were under investigation both in the United States and abroad, could pay a total of $3 billion, with the bulk expected to go to Brazil.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA STEVENSON and MATTHEW GOLDSTEIN

item.title: U.S. Blacklists 15 Russian Entities Linked to Ukraine and Crimea
item.description: The Treasury Department imposed targeted sanctions on seven officials and eight companies, creating an early test for the incoming Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: Turkey Assassination Suggests Erdogan’s Loyalty Problem Is Lingering
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan before delivering a speech on Tuesday in Istanbul. The assassination of the Russian ambassador by a Turkish police officer suggests that Mr. Erdogan may face a resilient disloyalty problem.
item.description: The affiliation of the man who killed Russia’s ambassador remains unclear, but the assassination betrayed a glaring unknown among forces that have pledged fealty to the president.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: War Crimes Proposal Would Help U.N. Build Cases on Syria
item.description: Diplomats are making a push to enable the United Nations to collect, preserve and analyze evidence of war crimes in Syria and prepare cases for a tribunal.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Explosion at Fireworks Market in Mexico Kills Dozens
item.description: The blast at the open-air San Pablito Market in Tultepec, on the outskirts of Mexico City, left at least 27 dead.
item.dc:creator: PAULINA VILLEGAS

item.title: How Rex Tillerson Changed His Tune on Russia and Came to Court Its Rulers
item.media:description: Rex W. Tillerson, chief executive of Exxon Mobil, in 2011. Mr. Tillerson can expect to be grilled at his Senate confirmation hearings on how he maintained access to Russia and its vast oil reserves at a time when Washington was trying to isolate Moscow.
item.description: Once a vocal critic of Russia’s justice system, the Exxon Mobil chief came to partner with the country’s biggest players. What will that history mean for the slated secretary of state?
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR and ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: In Turkey, a Capstone to a Violent Year. In Germany, a Realization of Fears.
item.media:description: A view of the scene where a truck crashed into a Christmas market next to the Kaiser Wilhelm Memorial Church in Berlin on Monday.
item.description: For Turkey, the murder of the Russian envoy was a bookend to one of the most turbulent years in its modern history. For Germany, the market attack pointed to an ominous future.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Pathum Thani Journal: Where Buddhism’s Eight-Fold Path Can Be Followed With a Six-Figure Salary
item.media:description: White-clad devotees at Dhammakaya Wat, Thailand’s largest temple, in February. The number of adherents has grown into the hundreds of thousands both in Thailand and abroad.
item.description: With its endorsement of worldly comforts, Wat Dhammakaya, the largest temple in Thailand, has attracted growing numbers while unsettling the government and Buddhist leaders.
item.dc:creator: SETH MYDANS

item.title: To Problems With China’s Financial System, Add the Bond Market
item.media:description: A brokerage house in Shanghai in November. China’s stock market crashed last year, and its $9 trillion bond market is showing signs of distress.
item.description: More than a year after the country’s stock market crashed, the $9 trillion bond market, a crucial part of efforts to overhaul the economy, is suffering.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: ISIS Is Said to Claim Responsibility for Deadly Attack in Jordan
item.media:description: The funeral on Monday of a high-ranking security officer killed in an assault in Karak, Jordan.
item.description: The assault in the southern city of Karak killed 10 people, including the head of the military’s special forces, two civilians and a Canadian tourist.
item.dc:creator: RANA F. SWEIS
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Philippines Should Investigate Rodrigo Duterte for Murder, U.N. Official Urges
item.media:description: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines, center, during a visit to Singapore this month. Mr. Duterte has said that he killed people when he was mayor of the city of Davao.
item.description: The country should pursue judicial proceedings after its president spoke of killing “about three” men, the United Nations high commissioner for human rights said.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Ankara, Berlin, Zurich: A Day of Terror
item.media:description: The truck that plowed through a crowd at a Christmas market in Berlin.
item.description: What is known about the violence in three countries.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Syria Talks Proceed Despite Assassination of Russian Diplomat in Turkey
item.media:description: Police special forces outside the Russian Consulate in central Istanbul on Tuesday, a day after the Russian ambassador to Turkey was killed by a gunman in Ankara.
item.description: The killing of Moscow’s envoy to Ankara has elicited widespread worry that relations between the nations might deteriorate.
item.dc:creator: OLEG MATSNEV and SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Germany Releases Berlin Attack Suspect as ISIS Claims Involvement
item.media:description: The path of destruction at the Christmas market in Berlin on Tuesday, after a truck that crashed through was removed from the site.
item.description: German officials, citing a lack of evidence, freed their initial suspect in the assault that killed 12, and continued to search for an attacker that the militant group said had acted on its behalf.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY and ALISON SMALE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Gunman Who Shot 3 at Zurich Islamic Center Is Found Dead, Police Say
item.description: The man, who apparently committed suicide after escaping from the site of the shooting, had no known links to terrorist groups, officials said.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and JACK EWING

item.title: Reflecting on a Hungary Escape 60 Years Ago, and on a Refugee’s Plight
item.media:description: Tom Leimdorfer at his home in Congresbury, near Bristol, England. He was 14 when he witnessed the 1956 uprising in Hungary, his homeland.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Tom Leimdorfer was just a boy when the Soviets crushed a 1956 uprising and his family fled for Britain. Decades later, Europe is again grappling with a mass migration.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Critic’s Notebook: Berlin Market Attack Mars Square Where Three Eras Coexist
item.media:description: The Christmas market last year at the Kaiser Wilhelm Memorial Church in Berlin.
item.media:credit: Jörg Carstensen/Deutsche Presse-Agentur, via Associated Press
item.description: At least 12 people were killed on Monday when a truck drove into a Christmas market in the shadow of the Kaiser Wilhelm Memorial Church, a site that has had layers of meaning.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

item.title: Searchers for Malaysia Jet Say They May Have Looked Too Far South
item.media:description: The police inspecting a piece of debris on the French-administered island of Réunion, off the southeastern coast of Africa, in July 2015. It was later identified as from the missing Malaysia Airlines plane.
item.description: Experts want to expand the search zone, but an Australian official said that would not happen unless new information about the location of the missing jet emerged.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (Australia)

item.title: Chinese Navy Returns Seized Underwater Drone to U.S.
item.media:description: The drone was launched by the Bowditch, an American ship, last week. Since the Pentagon demanded the return of the device, officials from the United States and China have verbally sparred over the legality of the seizure.
item.media:credit: U.S. Navy Visual News Service, via Associated Press
item.description: A Chinese vessel returned the submersible drone to a United States Navy ship in international waters off the Philippines, the Pentagon said.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Only a Rumbling Volcano Could Make North Korea and the West Play Nice
item.media:description: Mount Paektu, on the border between North Korea and China, erupted 1,000 years ago in one of the most violent volcanic explosions in human history.
item.description: Mount Paektu is sacred to the North Korean people. When a swarm of tiny earthquakes were recorded, the reclusive country decided it needed help.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS ST. FLEUR

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Israel Is Ready for a Reset at the U.N.
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu, prime minister of Israel, speaking to the United Nations General Assembly in September.
item.description: My country welcomes António Guterres as the United Nations’ new secretary general as an opportunity for a historic change in relations.
item.dc:creator: DANNY DANON

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: How Egyptian ‘Democracy’ Really Works
item.description: President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi has figured out how to maintain a simulacrum of democratic process. For whatever that’s worth.
item.dc:creator: EVAN HILL
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Why Venezuela Should Default
item.media:description: A sample bank note with the face of Venezuela’s President Maduro and the word “devaluated” is seen at a market in Caracas.
item.description: Postponing the inevitable will worsen the economy and is unfair to long-term creditors.
item.dc:creator: JOE KOGAN
